Brain MRI showed a diffuse infiltrating lesion centered in the pons measuring 3.2 cm in greatest dimension, with T2 hyperintensity and mild contrast enhancement. A stereotactic biopsy was performed, revealing a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma with WHO grade IV features. Molecular profiling demonstrated an H3F3A K27M mutation, concurrent TP53 loss‑of‑function, and PDGFRA amplification. The patient's calculated body surface area (BSA) is 1.3 m². He was enrolled in a phase II protocol consisting of conformal radiation therapy to a total dose of 54 Gy delivered in 30 fractions, with concurrent oral ONC201 administered at 125 mg/m² once weekly. After completing radiation, he entered a consolidation phase with the histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor panobinostat at a dose of 10 mg/m² administered orally on days 1‑5 of each 28‑day cycle; he completed two full cycles without dose reductions. The only reported adverse events were grade 1 nausea and transient thrombocytopenia (platelets 110 × 10⁹/L) that resolved without intervention. Follow‑up MRI at 3 months post‑radiation demonstrated interval progression of the pontine mass with new involvement of the middle cerebellar peduncles. The treating team considered enrollment in a new targeted‑therapy trial. The eligibility criteria for this trial are: (1) confirmed H3K27M mutation; (2) no prior exposure to any histone deacetylase inhibitor; and (3) a cumulative panobinostat exposure not exceeding 200 mg total across the study period. The trial protocol permits additional panobinostat dosing at 5 mg/m² on days 1‑5 of each 28‑day cycle, provided the cumulative dose limit is not breached.

Brain MRI demonstrated a diffusely infiltrative pontine lesion measuring 3.2 cm, hyperintense on T2, with mild contrast enhancement.
